awd_titl_txt: Supramolecular Self-Assembly and Capture as a New Route to 3D Cyclophanes
awd_abstract_narration:
Self-assembly -- a process analogous to a puzzle programmed to put itself together -- is a powerful tool for synthetic chemists to assemble large, complex organic molecules. This research program uses a self-assembly approach to develop highly efficient routes to complex, three-dimensional (3D) organic molecules known as "cyclophanes". These new chemical entities feature unusual properties in their interaction with light, the binding of "guest" molecules within their cage-like structures, and their ability to serve as precursors for polymeric materials (plastics). One broader impact of this research is the possible development of new building blocks for the parylene industrial polymerization process that provides polymer coatings for sensitive devices and electronics. Graduate student professional development activities continue to encourage the transfer of basic science discoveries to application. New professional development opportunities include implementing individual development plans, providing opportunities for internships, developing experience in mentorship, and supporting the Women in Graduate Sciences group at the University of Oregon. The involvement of undergraduate researchers in the program continues to be a priority as well. 

This project specifically seeks to advance a preliminary discovery showing that simple treatment of thiol ligands and a pnictogen source with iodine provides equilibrating thermodynamic mixtures of discrete disulfides that can be "kinetically trapped" via sulfur-extrusion chemistry to yield complex (thia)cyclophanes. This efficient two-step process of self-assembly and kinetic capture provides cyclophanes in scalable, high-yielding reactions.  This research seeks to advance these methods and to convert the self-assembled thiacyclophanes, which are known precursors to hydrocarbon cyclophanes, into new cyclophane compounds through three primary aims.  The researchers expand methods to synthesize new 2D and 3D self-assembled discrete disulfides using soft metal ions as directing elements. They also apply sulfur-extrusion chemistry to "kinetically trap" new thioether and hydrocarbon cyclophanes. Finally, the Johnson group scales-up the syntheses of new (hetero)cyclophanes and studies their initial properties. Cyclophanes are screened for their host-guest chemistry, optoelectronic properties, and use as monomers for new polymeric materials.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded fundamental science at the University of Oregon aimed at developing a "self-assembly" route to efficiently prepare cyclic 2-dimensional and cage-like 3-dimensional molecules from simple starting components.  Self-assembly -- a process analagous to a puzzle programmed to put itself together -- is a powerful tool for synthetic chemists to assemble large, complex organic molecules such as those studied under this award.  During this award, the lab developed facile methods to use disulfide bond self-assembly between multiple components to form large cyclic and/or cage-like molecules. Disulfides are a type of bond that form reversibly between two sulfur atoms, and they are responsible for giving curly hair its curly shape; in fact, the reversibility of disulfide bond formation allows the "hair perm" process to reshape straight hair into curls based on breaking and reforming such "disulfides". This project used similar methods to assemble smaller organic molecules into molecular rings and cages. Our lab then used existing methods to remove one sulfur atom from each of disulfide bonds to form more stable "thioether" rings and cages.  Removing the last sulfur atom, which proved successful in a few cases, allowed for formation of new hydrocarbons (a class of organic molecules possessing only carbon and hydrogen). These hydrocarbon species will be studied in future projects for their properties as precursors for new materials. One related molecule called parylene is a key monomer in the polymer industry used to make coatings for a variety of electronic and medical device applications. The new hydrocarbons formed in this project may hold promise in forming new parylene-type monomers for materials applications, and a key broader impact and outcome of this project was a US patent issued for our approach to making these compounds (U.S. Patent #9,790,192: Synthesis of Cyclophanes from a Self-Assembly Reaction). 

The intellectual merit of this project lies in showing these synthetic methods were effective at preparing dozens of new organic cyclic molecules and cages, and in several cases, our lab showed we could greatly improve laborious stepwise reactions to form existing structures of this type as well.  The Broader Impacts of this award lie in developing new organic compounds that could have application as new monomers for polymers and as "hosts" for smaller "guest" molecules.  Additional broader impacts of this award included professional development for graduate students on this project and in UO's Women in Graduate Sciences (WGS) group.  Students in the group performed internships at regional companies, performed individual development plans to develop a strategic plan for their careers post-graduation, and presented at numerous conferences and meetings. This award also supported WGS's workshop and seminar series to provide additional professional development for their members. In addition, many undergraduate researchers contributed to this project, with three earning authorship on peer-reviewed manuscripts supported by this award.

The key outcomes of this award include successful doctorates for the two senior students working on the project. One is now employed at a primarily undergraduate institution, and the other is a post-doctoral researcher at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. In addition to the patent issued from this award, the project also produced 8 peer-reviewed manuscripts. One of those papers appeared in one of the premeir chemistry journals and described how "Design of Experiments" (an engineering approach that is widely used to improve industrial processes and simplify complicated multi-variable experiments) is applicable to the type of "dynamic covalent" self-assembly chemistry developed under this award. This result led to optimized reaction conditions for the methods developed on the project, reduced waste by eliminating unnecessary experiments, and saved over one hundred hours of lab work by zeroing in on the key variables to adjust during reaction optimization. This Design of Experiments approach is now a key feature of the workflow on this project, and it represents intellectual merit developed under this award by streamlining experimental design on this project and into the future under renewal support from the NSF.


Last Modified: 10/14/2021
Modified by: Darren W Johnson
